docs.title: FirecREST Web UI Deployment with Helm
Overview
docs.text: This documentation provides step-by-step instructions for deploying the FirecREST Web UI using Helm on Kubernetes. The chart allows for flexible configuration using environment variables and supports custom branding, including logo customization.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Helm 3 installed on your local machine
  • Kubernetes cluster with appropriate access
  • ConfigMap for the custom logo (if enabled)

docs.title: 1. Add Helm Repository for FirecREST UI
docs.text:
Since the FirecREST Web UI is published as a Helm chart on GitHub, you can add it directly as a dependency:

dependencies:
  - name: firecrest-web-ui-v2
    version: <version>
    repository: https://eth-cscs.github.io/firecrest-ui/helm/

To add the Helm repository manually:

helm repo add firecrest-ui https://eth-cscs.github.io/firecrest-ui/helm/
helm repo update

docs.title: 2. Clone the Helm Chart Repository
docs.text:
git clone <repository-url>
cd <repository-directory>

docs.title: 3. Update Values File (values.yaml)
docs.text:
Customize the deployment by editing the values.yaml file. Below are the most common configurations:

replicas: 2
image: "ghcr.io/eth-cscs/firecrest-ui"
loggingLevel: "info"
fileUploadLimit: "5MB"

companyName: "MyCompany"
appName: "MyPlatform"
customLogo: true
customLogoVolume: "/usr/server/app/public/custom/logo.svg"
customLogoPath: "./custom/logo.svg"

keycloakDomain: "auth.example.com"
keycloakRealm: "myrealm"
keycloakCallbackUrl: "https://webui.example.com/callback"
keycloakLogoutRedirectUrl: "https://webui.example.com/logout"
firecrestApiBaseUrl: "https://api.example.com"
redisActive: "true"
redisHost: "redis.example.com"
supportUrl: "https://support.example.com"
docUrl: "https://docs.example.com"
repoUrl: "https://github.com/example/repo"

docs.title: 4. Deploy the Helm Chart
docs.text: helm upgrade --install firecrest ./chart --values values.yaml

docs.title: 5. Verify the Deployment
docs.text:
kubectl get deployments
kubectl get pods -l app=firecrest-web-ui

docs.title: Custom Logo Configuration
docs.text:
To enable a custom logo:

  1. Update values.yaml to enable branding:
customLogo: true
customLogoVolume: "/usr/server/app/public/custom/logo.svg"
customLogoPath: "./custom/logo.svg"
  1. Create the ConfigMap with the custom logo:

In this example we provide the FirecREST svg logo. 

apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: firecrest-logo
  namespace: default
data:
  logo.svg: |
    <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 127.45 125.91" width="100" height="100">
      <defs>
        <style>
          .cls-2 {
            fill: #7a7a7a;
          }
        </style>
      </defs>
      <path
        d="M2.38 61.642L23.177 40.846l20.796 20.796-20.796 20.796zM.05 105.38l20.8-20.79-20.8-20.8v41.59zM98.86 96.5H69.45v29.41L98.86 96.5zM67.66 93.34l27.48-27.48 27.49 27.48H67.66zM66.38 125.67l-41-41 41-41v82zM127.45 29.03H69.47v57.98l57.98-57.98z"
        class="cls-2"
      />
      <path
        d="M31.03 0L0 30.64l.08 28.71 30.89-30.48L31.03 0z"
        style="fill: #ec671a;"
      />
    </svg>

docs.title: Conditional Logo Mounting
docs.text:
In the deployment.yaml, make sure to conditionally include the volume and volumeMount only when the custom logo flag is set:

{{- if .Values.customLogo }}
volumeMounts:
  - name: logo-volume
    mountPath: {{ .Values.customLogoVolume }}
    subPath: logo.svg
{{- end }}

{{- if .Values.customLogo }}
volumes:
  - name: logo-volume
    configMap:
      name: firecrest-logo
{{- end }}

docs.title: Accessing the Application
docs.text:
Once deployed, access the application via the configured hostname:

http://webui.example.com

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Check logs if the deployment fails:
kubectl logs -l app=firecrest-web-ui
  • Validate environment variables:
kubectl describe pod -l app=firecrest-web-ui

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.text:
To uninstall the Helm chart:

helm uninstall firecrest

docs.title: Dashboard
docs.text: The dashboard provides an overview of accessible clusters and their statuses. It also displays currently running jobs.

docs.title: Job Scheduler View
docs.text: The Job Scheduler lists all jobs and includes functionality to schedule new jobs.

docs.title: Schedule a Job
docs.text: The "Submit a Job" button, located at the top-right corner of the Job Scheduler view, opens a form to schedule a new job.

docs.title: Job Details
docs.text: Job details can be viewed on a dedicated page, depending on the job's status. A tabbed interface allows users to view the running script, as well as the standard output and error logs.

docs.title: File Manager
docs.text:
The File Manager view lists files on a specific cluster. Users can navigate through the file structure and perform basic file operations (e.g., copy, move).

Additionally, users can upload or download files. File uploads are handled transparently based on file size: - Files smaller than 5MB are uploaded directly. - Larger files require a file upload process involving a scheduled file transfer job (typically via S3 storage).

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Node.js >= 22.0.0
  • Yarn

docs.title: Backend Configuration
docs.text: To connect the UI with the backend, create a .env file based on the provided env_example file. The variables in the .env file should be configured according to the backend environment you intend to use.

docs.title: Local Backend Setup
docs.text: To simplify running the FirecREST API locally, we provide a set of Docker environments pre-configured with all required dependencies. Ensure Docker is installed and running on your machine. Follow the instructions for local development of the FirecREST API v2.

docs.title: Remote Backend Setup
docs.text: If your infrastructure includes a remote FirecREST API instance, update your .env file accordingly to connect to the remote backend.

docs.title: Local UI Development with a Local FirecREST Environment
Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure the following tools are installed: 

node --version
yarn --version

docs.title: Steps to Run the UI Locally
docs.text:
1. Install dependencies: 

    yarn install

  2. Start the development server: 

    yarn run dev

  3. Open the UI in your browser at http://localhost:3000/. You should see a login page (Keycloak).

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Use the following credentials to log in: 

Client: fireuser
Secret: password

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Ensure all dependencies are up-to-date for a smooth development experience.
  • Refer to the FirecREST API documentation for additional backend configuration details.
  • For troubleshooting, consult the project's issue tracker or documentation.

docs.title: FirecREST v2 UI
docs.text:
FirecREST UI is a web application designed to provide essential functionalities for interacting with FirecREST API v2 backend.

FirecREST offers a REST API that enables developers to interact with HPC resources such as schedulers, filesystems, and more. Additionally, it provides methods for authentication, authorization, job execution, file-system operations, and access to accounting or status information.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• A modern web interface built on FirecREST API functionalities.
  • A dashboard offering an overview of configured clusters and their statuses.
  • A dedicated view for creating and monitoring jobs.
  • A file navigator with basic file management functionalities, including upload and download features.

While the FirecREST API empowers users to build complex workflows, a workflow manager is not included in the current web interface implementation.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• An open-source web UI compatible with the FirecREST API v2.
  • A convenient alternative for monitoring and managing jobs.
  • Integration with backend Identity and Access Management (IAM).

docs.title: Technologies
docs.text: 📖 Refer to the Remix documentation and the Remix Vite documentation for detailed information on supported features.
